title: Octavian holds the first of three consecutive triumphs in Rome to celebrate the victory over the Dalmatian tribes.
text: • 29 BC – Octavian holds the first of three consecutive triumphs in Rome to celebrate the victory over the Dalmatian tribes.

title: John I becomes the new Pope after the death of Pope Hormisdas.
text: • 523 – John I becomes the new Pope after the death of Pope Hormisdas.

title: Emperor Justinian I rewards Liberius for his long and distinguished service in the Pragmatic Sanction, granting him extensive estates in Italy.
text: • 554 – Emperor Justinian I rewards Liberius for his long and distinguished service in the Pragmatic Sanction, granting him extensive estates in Italy.

title: Maurice becomes Emperor of the Byzantine Empire.
text: • 582 – Maurice becomes Emperor of the Byzantine Empire.

title: Count Reginar I of Hainault rises against Zwentibold of Lotharingia and slays him near present
text: • 900 – Count Reginar I of Hainault rises against Zwentibold of Lotharingia and slays him near present-day Susteren.

title: Raniero is elected as Pope Paschal II.
text: • 1099 – Raniero is elected as Pope Paschal II.

title: The Treaty of Noyon between France and Spain is signed. Francis I of France recognizes Charles's claim to Naples, and Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, recognizes Francis's claim to Milan.
text: • 1516 – The Treaty of Noyon between France and Spain is signed. Francis I of France recognizes Charles's claim to Naples, and Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor, recognizes Francis's claim to Milan.

title: After an extended siege, forces led by Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés capture Tlatoani Cuauhtémoc and conquer the Aztec capital of Tenochtitlan.
text: • 1521 – After an extended siege, forces led by Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés capture Tlatoani Cuauhtémoc and conquer the Aztec capital of Tenochtitlan.

title: Union of Brittany and France: The Duchy of Brittany is absorbed into the Kingdom of France.
text: • 1532 – Union of Brittany and France: The Duchy of Brittany is absorbed into the Kingdom of France.

title: Buddhist monks from Kyoto, Japan's Enryaku
text: • 1536 – Buddhist monks from Kyoto, Japan's Enryaku-ji temple set fire to 21 Nichiren temples throughout in what will be known as the Tenbun Hokke Disturbance. (Traditional Japanese date: July 27, 1536).

title: Michael Servetus is arrested by John Calvin in Geneva, Switzerland as a heretic.
text: • 1553 – Michael Servetus is arrested by John Calvin in Geneva, Switzerland as a heretic.

title: The French king Louis XIII appoints Cardinal Richelieu as prime minister.
text: • 1624 – The French king Louis XIII appoints Cardinal Richelieu as prime minister.

title: Sweden and Denmark sign Peace of Brömsebro.
text: • 1645 – Sweden and Denmark sign Peace of Brömsebro.

title: War of the Spanish Succession: Battle of Blenheim: English and Imperial forces are victorious over French and Bavarian troops.
text: • 1704 – War of the Spanish Succession: Battle of Blenheim: English and Imperial forces are victorious over French and Bavarian troops.

title: American Revolutionary War: The Royal Navy defeats the Penobscot Expedition with the most significant loss of United States naval forces prior to the attack on Pearl Harbor.
text: • 1779 – American Revolutionary War: The Royal Navy defeats the Penobscot Expedition with the most significant loss of United States naval forces prior to the attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: King Louis XVI of France is formally arrested by the National Tribunal, and declared an enemy of the people.
text: • 1792 – King Louis XVI of France is formally arrested by the National Tribunal, and declared an enemy of the people.

title: Battle of Mišar during the Serbian Revolution begins. The battle will end two days later, with a decisive Serbian victory over the Ottomans.
text: • 1806 – Battle of Mišar during the Serbian Revolution begins. The battle will end two days later, with a decisive Serbian victory over the Ottomans.

title: The Convention of London, a treaty between the United Kingdom and the United Provinces, is signed in London, England.
text: • 1814 – The Convention of London, a treaty between the United Kingdom and the United Provinces, is signed in London, England.

title: The 8.5
text: • 1868 – The 8.5–9.0 Mw Arica earthquake struck southern Peru with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), causing 25,000+ deaths and a destructive basin wide tsunami that affected Hawaii and New Zealand.

title: William Gray of Hartford, Connecticut is granted United States Patent Number 408,709 for "Coin
text: • 1889 – William Gray of Hartford, Connecticut is granted United States Patent Number 408,709 for "Coin-controlled apparatus for telephones." [1]

title: Spanish
text: • 1898 – Spanish–American War: Spanish and American forces engage in a mock battle for Manila, after which the Spanish commander surrendered in order to keep the city out of Filipino rebel hands.

title: Carl Gustav Witt discovers 433 Eros, the first near
text: • 1898 – Carl Gustav Witt discovers 433 Eros, the first near-Earth asteroid to be found.

title: Norwegians vote to end the union with Sweden.
text: • 1905 – Norwegians vote to end the union with Sweden.

title: The all black infantrymen of the U.S. Army's 25th Infantry Regiment are accused of killing a white bartender and wounding a white police officer in Brownsville, Texas, despite exculpatory evidence; all are later dishonorably discharged. (Their records were later restored to reflect honorable discharges but there were no financial settlements.
text: • 1906 – The all black infantrymen of the U.S. Army's 25th Infantry Regiment are accused of killing a white bartender and wounding a white police officer in Brownsville, Texas, despite exculpatory evidence; all are later dishonorably discharged. (Their records were later restored to reflect honorable discharges but there were no financial settlements.

title: First production in the UK of stainless steel by Harry Brearley.
text: • 1913 – First production in the UK of stainless steel by Harry Brearley.

title: Women enlist in the United States Marine Corps for the first time. Opha May Johnson is the first woman to enlist.
text: • 1918 – Women enlist in the United States Marine Corps for the first time. Opha May Johnson is the first woman to enlist.

title: Bayerische Motoren Werke AG (BMW) established as a public company in Germany.
text: • 1918 – Bayerische Motoren Werke AG (BMW) established as a public company in Germany.

title: Polish
text: • 1920 – Polish–Soviet War: The Battle of Warsaw begins and will last till August 25. The Red Army is defeated.

title: Second Sino
text: • 1937 – Second Sino-Japanese War: The Battle of Shanghai begins.

title: Major General Eugene Reybold of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers authorizes the construction of facilities that would house the "Development of Substitute Materials" project, better known as the Manhattan Project.
text: • 1942 – Major General Eugene Reybold of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers authorizes the construction of facilities that would house the "Development of Substitute Materials" project, better known as the Manhattan Project.

title: World War II: German troops begin the pillage and razing of Anogeia in Crete that would continue until September 5.
text: • 1944 – World War II: German troops begin the pillage and razing of Anogeia in Crete that would continue until September 5.

title: Radio Pakistan broadcasts the "Qaumī Tarāna", the national anthem of Pakistan for the first time.
text: • 1954 – Radio Pakistan broadcasts the "Qaumī Tarāna", the national anthem of Pakistan for the first time.

title: The Central African Republic declares independence from France.
text: • 1960 – The Central African Republic declares independence from France.

title: Cold War: East Germany closes the border between the eastern and western sectors of Berlin to thwart its inhabitants' attempts to escape to the West, and construction of the Berlin Wall is started.[2]
text: • 1961 – Cold War: East Germany closes the border between the eastern and western sectors of Berlin to thwart its inhabitants' attempts to escape to the West, and construction of the Berlin Wall is started.[2]

title: Peter Allen and Gwynne Evans are hanged for the Murder of John Alan West becoming the last people executed in the United Kingdom.
text: • 1964 – Peter Allen and Gwynne Evans are hanged for the Murder of John Alan West becoming the last people executed in the United Kingdom.

title: Alexandros Panagoulis attempts to assassinate the Greek dictator Colonel Georgios Papadopoulos in Varkiza, Athens.
text: • 1968 – Alexandros Panagoulis attempts to assassinate the Greek dictator Colonel Georgios Papadopoulos in Varkiza, Athens.

title: The Apollo 11 astronauts enjoy a ticker tape parade in New York City.[3] That evening, at a state dinner in Los Angeles, they are awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by U.S. President Richard Nixon.[4]
text: • 1969 – The Apollo 11 astronauts enjoy a ticker tape parade in New York City.[3] That evening, at a state dinner in Los Angeles, they are awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by U.S. President Richard Nixon.[4]

title: Members of the British National Front (NF) clash with anti
text: • 1977 – Members of the British National Front (NF) clash with anti-NF demonstrators in Lewisham, London, resulting in 214 arrests and at least 111 injuries.

title: One hundred fifty Palestinians in Beirut are killed in a terrorist attack during the second phase of the Lebanese Civil War.
text: • 1978 – One hundred fifty Palestinians in Beirut are killed in a terrorist attack during the second phase of the Lebanese Civil War.

title: One hundred fifty
text: • 2004 – One hundred fifty-six Congolese Tutsi refugees are massacred at the Gatumba refugee camp in Burundi.

title: Russo
text: • 2008 – Russo-Georgian War: Russian units occupy the Georgian city of Gori.

title: At least 76 people are killed and 212 others are wounded in a truck bombing in Baghdad, Iraq.
text: • 2015 – At least 76 people are killed and 212 others are wounded in a truck bombing in Baghdad, Iraq.
